TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit ContractDescription extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Describes a Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) contract that specifies what an endpoint communicates to the outside world.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A [!INCLUDE[indigo2](~/includes/indigo2-md.md)] contract is a collection of operations that specifies what the endpoint communicates to the outside world. Each operation is a message exchange. For example, a request message and an associated reply message form a request/reply message exchange.
A <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription> object is used to describe [!INCLUDE[indigo2](~/includes/indigo2-md.md)] contracts and their operations. Within a <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription>, each contract operation has a corresponding <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.OperationDescription> that describes aspects of the each operation that is part of the contract, such as whether the operation is one-way or request/reply. Each <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.OperationDescription> also describes the messages that make up the operation using a <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.MessageDescriptionCollection>. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription> contains a reference to an interface that defines the contract using the programming model. This interface is marked with <xref:System.ServiceModel.ServiceContractAttribute> and its methods that correspond to endpoint operations are marked with the <xref:System.ServiceModel.OperationContractAttribute>.
A *duplex* contract defines the following logical sets of operations:
- A set that the service exposes for the client to call.
- A set that the client exposes for the service to call.
The programming model for defining a duplex contract is to split each set in a separate interface and apply attributes to each interface. In this case, <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription> contains a reference to each of the interfaces that groups them into one duplex contract.
Similar to bindings, each contract has a <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription.Name%2A> and <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription.Namespace%2A> that uniquely identify it in the metadata of the service.
## Examples The following example shows a number of ways to create or retrieve a <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription> object. It then displays the various pieces of information that are stored in the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription> object.
[!code-csharp[S_UE_ContractDescription#0](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_CFX/s_ue_contractdescription/cs/calculatorservice.cs#0)] [!code-vb[S_UE_ContractDescription#0](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_CFX/s_ue_contractdescription/vb/calculatorservice.vb#0)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the type of callback contract that the contract description specifies.
Docs.value: The of callback contract that the contract description specifies.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription.CallbackContractType%2A> property is not serializable, so it is only available when the description is bound to runtime. It cannot be imported or exported as part of the metadata.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The difference between the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription.GetContract%2A> overloads is that the ones with two arguments allow you to find attributes from the service (for example, <xref:System.ServiceModel.OperationBehaviorAttribute>).

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the contract has had a protection level set.
Docs.value: if the protection level has been set; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks When the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription.ProtectionLevel%2A> is set, the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Description.ContractDescription.HasProtectionLevel%2A> property is set to `true`.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether a session is required by the contract.
Docs.value: The that specifies the support for reliable sessions that a contract requires or supports.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A reliable session is a way of correlating a set of messages exchanged between two or more endpoints (using the [WS-ReliableMessaging](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=96680) specification) to provide assurances of the reliability of the connection.
